speaker_1.speaker: thorne
speaker_1.text: Captain. Mind if I join you?

speaker_2.speaker: thorne
speaker_2.text: I've been with a dozen companies over the years. Most of them are dead now. You know why?

speaker_3.speaker: thorne
speaker_3.text: Idealism. Captains who thought they could be heroes. Who took contracts for 'the right reasons' instead of the right coin. This work isn't about glory - it's about survival. Gold keeps us fed, steel keeps us alive.

speaker_4.speaker: thorne
speaker_4.text: So I have to ask, Captain... what are you in this for?

choice_agree.text: Gold and survival. Same as you.

choice_disagree.text: There's more to life than coin.

choice_ask.text: What happened to those other companies?

speaker_agree.speaker: thorne
speaker_agree.text: *nods* Good. A practical captain. That's rare. We might just survive this after all.

speaker_disagree.speaker: thorne
speaker_disagree.text: *sighs* I've heard that before. From captains who are rotting in unmarked graves now. I hope you prove me wrong, but I won't hold my breath.

speaker_ask_1.speaker: thorne
speaker_ask_1.text: *pauses* ...You actually want to know? Most just want yes-men, not stories.

speaker_ask_2.speaker: thorne
speaker_ask_2.text: The last company I served with - the Red Shields - took a contract defending a village that couldn't pay. 'It's the right thing to do,' the captain said.

speaker_ask_3.speaker: thorne
speaker_ask_3.text: We won. And then we starved because we had no coin for the winter. Half of us died before spring.

speaker_ask_4.speaker: thorne
speaker_ask_4.text: I learned something that year, Captain. Good intentions don't fill bellies. But you asking... that's something. Most captains don't care what their soldiers think.

speaker_closing.speaker: thorne
speaker_closing.text: Anyway. Get some rest. Tomorrow we see what other work Ironmark has for sellswords like us.
